did.abstract: This collection contains the papers of Michael Radelet.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted, except for a select number of folders indicated in the finding aid.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: All items in this collection were transferred to the University Libraries, M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives by Michael Radelet in 2013, 2015, and 2017.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically, and there are no series.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Michael Radelet is a professor of Sociology at the University of Colorado at Boulder and a long-time scholar of capital punishment, criminology, deviance and the sociology of law, and medical sociology.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Michael Radelet Papers, 1976-2015. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the Radelet Papers).

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Michael David Munsey processed this collection in 2025. Instead of dividing the collection into small series, the archivist added the name of the relevant publication or research category to the beginning of each folder's title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains research materials on capital punishment cases in articles or book used by Radelet in articles and book chapters, including Executions of Whites for Crimes Against Blacks (1989), Executive Clemency in Post-Furman Cases (1993), and On Botched Executions (with co-author Marian J. Borg), which appeared in Capital Punishment, Strategies for Abolition. Materials also include research files on individuals who were wrongfully convicted and/or executed, which were used in the writing of two publications co-authored with Hugo Bedau: Miscarriages of Justice in Potentially Capital Cases (1987) and In Spite of Innocence (1992). Finally, the collection contains research files on cases that Bedau and Radelet considered for inclusion in publications but ultimately rejected. Radelet arranged the materials according to these categories and publications.

The collection includes the following types of materials: affidavits; appeals for clemency; artwork; bibliographies; book manuscripts; book reviews; brochures; business cards; calendars; cassette tapes; closing remarks from conferences; copies of articles and chapters authored or co-authored by Radelet himself; copies of articles on capital punishment by other authors; correspondence, including letters between Radelet and Bedau and various archives, attorneys, colleagues, such as Watt Espy, government officials, and incarcerated or formerly incarcerated individuals; curricula vitae; death certificates; drafts of book chapters; emails; fact sheets concerning cases; fax cover sheets; documentary film materials; findings aids from archives; flyers from activist groups; interlibrary loan requests; legislative bills; letters of agreement; lists and tables concerning those wrongly convicted; logs from correctional facilities; magazines and magazine clippings; memoranda; news articles from electronic databases; newspapers and newspaper clippings; notes about missed phone calls; package slips; pamphlets from activist groups; photocopies of books, correspondence, newsletters, newspapers, and magazines; photocopies of court and legal documents; photocopy orders; postage lables; press releases; questionnaries completed by incarcerated individuals; reports; research notes; shipping invoices; state governors' orders, pardons, proclamations, and statements; state historical quarterly publications; surveys; transcripts of interviews and public hearings; and webpages
